Claim: Post says “people of color may be immune to the coronavirus because of melanin.”
Explaination: Melanin is a natural pigment that gives color to skin and eyes. It does not make you any less susceptible to coronavirus.
Label: False
html:
Claim: Post says “people of color may be immune to the coronavirus because of melanin.”

Explanation:Melanin is a natural pigment that gives color to skin and eyes. It does not make you any less susceptible to coronavirus.

https://www.politifact.com/factchecks/2020/mar/10/facebook-posts/melanin-doesnt-protect-against-coronavirus/

Claim: Anti-Malaria Drug Chloroquine Is A Cure For Coronavirus.
Explaination: Anti- Malaria drug Chloroquine is not an authorized medicine to cure coronavirus. There is no scientific evidence to prove that Chloroquine can be used to cure COVID-19.
Label: False
html:
Claim: Anti-Malaria Drug Chloroquine Is A Cure For Coronavirus.

Explanation:Anti- Malaria drug Chloroquine is not an authorized medicine to cure coronavirus. There is no scientific evidence to prove that Chloroquine can be used to cure COVID-19.

https://english.factcrescendo.com/2020/03/12/no-anti-malaria-drug-chloroquine-is-not-a-cure-for-coronavirus/

Claim: Photo posts claim a person is committing suicide by jumping from a building in Italy, a doctor couple in an Italian hospital a few hours before their death and chaos in an Italian hospital amid COVID-19.
Explaination: The first image is from Spain where a woman committed suicide in December 2019, The second image is of a couple at the Barcelona airport and the third image is from recent earthquake in Croatia.
Label: False
html:
Claim: Photo posts claim a person is committing suicide by jumping from a building in Italy, a doctor couple in an Italian hospital a few hours before their death and chaos in an Italian hospital amid COVID-19.

Explanation:The first image is from Spain where a woman committed suicide in December 2019, The second image is of a couple at the Barcelona airport and the third image is from recent earthquake in Croatia.

https://srilanka.factcrescendo.com/2020/03/26/fact-check-series-of-old-and-unrelated-images-shared-as-current-situation-in-italy-related-with-covid19/

Claim: Clapping together at 5 p.m. will create a vibration which will destroy coronavirus.
Explaination: There is no proven evidence that vibration created by collectively clapping can destroy coronavirus.
Label: Mostly false
html:
Claim: Clapping together at 5 p.m. will create a vibration which will destroy coronavirus.

Explanation:There is no proven evidence that vibration created by collectively clapping can destroy coronavirus.

https://www.indiatoday.in/fact-check/story/fact-check-no-clapping-together-at-5-pm-during-janta-curfew-will-not-kill-coronavirus-1658438-2020-03-22

Claim: Bill Gates helped fund a patent for coronavirus.
Explaination: The Pirbright Institute addressed the conspiracy theories and said the patents involve infectious bronchitis virus (IBV) only, and the Gates Foundation did not fund that work.
Label: False
html:
Claim: Bill Gates helped fund a patent for coronavirus.

Explanation:The Pirbright Institute addressed the conspiracy theories and said the patents involve infectious bronchitis virus (IBV) only, and the Gates Foundation did not fund that work.

https://hoax-alert.leadstories.com/3471583-fake-news-bill-gates-did-not-help-fund-patent-for-coronavirus.html

Claim: A post says that there is a movie that predicted the pandemic and it’s called “Coronavirus”.
Explaination: The image is false, is manipulated and it uses the cover of the movie “The flu” with the wrong title. There’s no movie called “Coronavirus”.
Label: FALSE
html:
Claim: A post says that there is a movie that predicted the pandemic and it’s called “Coronavirus”.

Explanation:The image is false, is manipulated and it uses the cover of the movie “The flu” with the wrong title. There’s no movie called “Coronavirus”.

https://observador.pt/factchecks/fact-check-filme-de-2013-previa-epidemia-e-chamava-se-coronavirus/

Claim: Garlic soup can cure the coronavirus.
Explaination: The claim is false as according to the WHO no treatment has yet been found for coronavirus. The search is still on.
Label: False
html:
Claim: Garlic soup can cure the coronavirus.

Explanation:The claim is false as according to the WHO no treatment has yet been found for coronavirus. The search is still on.

https://www.newschecker.in/article/news-detail/275_14705792

Claim: Vladimir Putin let lions loose in the streets of Russia to keep them indoors amid COVID-19.
Explaination: The image is from Johannesburg, South Africa, where a lion was released for a video shooting.
Label: False
html:
Claim: Vladimir Putin let lions loose in the streets of Russia to keep them indoors amid COVID-19.

Explanation:The image is from Johannesburg, South Africa, where a lion was released for a video shooting.

https://www.boomlive.in/fake-news/putin-let-loose-lions-to-keep-russians-indoors-bizarre-claim-goes-viral-7320

Claim: A Facebook user shared a video that shows dead bodies being washed ashore at some unidentified beach.
Explaination: The video doing rounds on social media has no connection with the coronavirus pandemic. The disturbing video doing rounds is of the bodies of African immigrants washing onto the shore of al-Qarbole, after a boat carrying 200 illegal immigrants from sub-Saharan Africa sunk off the Libyan capital.
Label: FALSE
html:
Claim: A Facebook user shared a video that shows dead bodies being washed ashore at some unidentified beach.

Explanation:The video doing rounds on social media has no connection with the coronavirus pandemic. The disturbing video doing rounds is of the bodies of African immigrants washing onto the shore of al-Qarbole, after a boat carrying 200 illegal immigrants from sub-Saharan Africa sunk off the Libyan capital.

https://www.newschecker.in/article/news-detail/275_15582658

Claim: President Donald Trump claims he “didn’t say that” some of the medical equipment that governors are requesting, they don’t actually need.
Explaination: During the interview with Hannity, Trump said, “I have a feeling that a lot of the numbers (for ventilators) that are being said in some areas are just bigger than they're going to be. I don't believe you need 40,000 or 30,000 ventilators.”
Label: Pants on Fire!
html:
Claim: President Donald Trump claims he “didn’t say that” some of the medical equipment that governors are requesting, they don’t actually need.

Explanation:During the interview with Hannity, Trump said, “I have a feeling that a lot of the numbers (for ventilators) that are being said in some areas are just bigger than they're going to be. I don't believe you need 40,000 or 30,000 ventilators.”

https://www.politifact.com/factchecks/2020/mar/30/donald-trump/reporter-was-right-trump-did-question/

Claim: Ministry of Home Affairs in India has directed people to not post anything related to coronavirus.
Explaination: The message has been undersigned by the Principal Secretary to the Home Minister but in reality there is no such post of person in the ministry.
Label: False
html:
Claim: Ministry of Home Affairs in India has directed people to not post anything related to coronavirus.

Explanation:The message has been undersigned by the Principal Secretary to the Home Minister but in reality there is no such post of person in the ministry.

Claim: Coronavirus infects chickens in Pakistan.
Explaination: Authorities say it's related to another disease.
Label: False
html:
Claim: Coronavirus infects chickens in Pakistan.

Explanation:Authorities say it's related to another disease.

Explaination: The CDC still reports that there is "currently no vaccine to prevent" and "no specific antiviral treatment recommended" for the novel coronavirus, or COVID-19.

html:

Explanation:The CDC still reports that there is "currently no vaccine to prevent" and "no specific antiviral treatment recommended" for the novel coronavirus, or COVID-19.

Claim: Coronavirus has killed 112,000 people and infected 2,800,000 in China.
Explaination: Till the time of writing this article, coronavirus had killed more than 400 people and infected over 20,000 in China.
Label: Mostly false
html:
Claim: Coronavirus has killed 112,000 people and infected 2,800,000 in China.

Explanation:Till the time of writing this article, coronavirus had killed more than 400 people and infected over 20,000 in China.

Claim: Whether CDC had scheduled announcement that all should wear masks for everyday life.
Explaination: At the time, the CDC confirmed they had nothing scheduled.
Label: False
html:
Claim: Whether CDC had scheduled announcement that all should wear masks for everyday life.

Explanation:At the time, the CDC confirmed they had nothing scheduled.

https://leadstories.com/hoax-alert/2020/03/fact-check-cdc-is-not-scheduled-to-recommend-masks-for-everyday-life.html

Claim: A post shared repeatedly on WhatsApp and Facebook claims a Chinese doctor has discovered that drinking tea is effective in curing and relieving symptoms of the novel coronavirus, COVID-19.
Explaination: The claim is false; health experts say there is insufficient scientific evidence to show that drinking tea is effective in preventing or curing COVID-19 infections; as of March 2020, the World Health Organization (WHO) has said there is no cure for COVID-19.
Label: False
html:
Claim: A post shared repeatedly on WhatsApp and Facebook claims a Chinese doctor has discovered that drinking tea is effective in curing and relieving symptoms of the novel coronavirus, COVID-19.

Explanation:The claim is false; health experts say there is insufficient scientific evidence to show that drinking tea is effective in preventing or curing COVID-19 infections; as of March 2020, the World Health Organization (WHO) has said there is no cure for COVID-19.

https://factcheck.afp.com/no-evidence-drinking-tea-can-cure-or-relieve-symptoms-covid-19-doctors-say

Claim: Videos of people infected with the new coronavirus in China.
Explaination: In both cases, it can't corroborate the origin of the material. Besides, does not exist an official pronouncement of any Chinese authority in health matter.
Label: No evidence
html:
Claim: Videos of people infected with the new coronavirus in China.

Explanation:In both cases, it can't corroborate the origin of the material. Besides, does not exist an official pronouncement of any Chinese authority in health matter.

https://spondeomedia.com/sin-sustento-videos-de-personas-infectadas-de-coronavirus-en-china/

Claim: There is now a COVID-19 cure from the USA.
Explaination: It was a test kit from South Korea, that was shared as an American-made vaccine for COVID-19.
Label: False
html:
Claim: There is now a COVID-19 cure from the USA.

Explanation:It was a test kit from South Korea, that was shared as an American-made vaccine for COVID-19.

https://srilanka.factcrescendo.com/2020/03/30/fact-check-test-kit-from-south-korea-shared-as-covid19-vaccine/

Claim: Gargling with warm water and salt or vinegar eliminates the coronavirus.
Explaination: There is no evidence to suggest that gargling salt water or vinegar, or partaking in many other home remedies, fight SARS-CoV-2 infection. Upon entering the body, the virus attaches to and enters cells in the airway where it takes over the cells’ machinery, producing more viral particles that spread to other cells. Because the virus hides out in the body’s own cells, it can not be targeted without also killing healthy, uninfected cells. Therefore, fighting viral infections relies on the body’s immune response.
Label: False
html:
Claim: Gargling with warm water and salt or vinegar eliminates the coronavirus.

Explanation:There is no evidence to suggest that gargling salt water or vinegar, or partaking in many other home remedies, fight SARS-CoV-2 infection. Upon entering the body, the virus attaches to and enters cells in the airway where it takes over the cells’ machinery, producing more viral particles that spread to other cells. Because the virus hides out in the body’s own cells, it can not be targeted without also killing healthy, uninfected cells. Therefore, fighting viral infections relies on the body’s immune response.

https://healthfeedback.org/claimreview/gargling-salt-water-or-vinegar-may-soothe-a-sore-throat-but-it-will-not-eliminate-covid-19/

Claim: As of 3/7/20, Tanzania and Zambia had confirmed fist cases of the new coronavirus.
Explaination: At the time, the MP said there were no reported cases in Tanzania. WHO also didn't confirm cases at the time in either country.
Label: False
html:
Claim: As of 3/7/20, Tanzania and Zambia had confirmed fist cases of the new coronavirus.

Explanation:At the time, the MP said there were no reported cases in Tanzania. WHO also didn't confirm cases at the time in either country.

https://hoax-alert.leadstories.com/3471853-fact-check-tanzania-confirms-first-case-of-coronavirus---mcm.html

Claim: A post says the coronavirus can be slowed or stopped with the “immediate widespread use of high doses of vitamin C.”
Explaination: The claim was originally shared on an alternative medical website that promotes nutritional supplementation.
Label: FALSE
html:
Claim: A post says the coronavirus can be slowed or stopped with the “immediate widespread use of high doses of vitamin C.”

Explanation:The claim was originally shared on an alternative medical website that promotes nutritional supplementation.

https://www.politifact.com/factchecks/2020/feb/29/facebook-posts/no-vitamin-c-cannot-slow-or-stop-spread-coronaviru/

Claim: The quarantine in Italy showed more clean waters in Venice with fish and a dolphin.
Explaination: It is not true, the image of a dolphin was taken in another Italian city, Cagliari, in the Sardinia island, and not in Venice. It was not due to the quarantine.
Label: False
html:
Claim: The quarantine in Italy showed more clean waters in Venice with fish and a dolphin.

Explanation:It is not true, the image of a dolphin was taken in another Italian city, Cagliari, in the Sardinia island, and not in Venice. It was not due to the quarantine.

https://observador.pt/2020/03/21/cisnes-e-golfinhos-em-veneza-nao-aguas-estao-mais-limpas-mas-a-vida-selvagem-nao-mudou/

Claim: Russian President Vladimir Putin releases 800 tigers and 500 lions amid the coronavirus outbreak to keep people at home.
Explaination: The photos used were taken in 2016 and 2019 respectively, both in South Africa.
Label: False
html:
Claim: Russian President Vladimir Putin releases 800 tigers and 500 lions amid the coronavirus outbreak to keep people at home.

Explanation:The photos used were taken in 2016 and 2019 respectively, both in South Africa.

https://www.rappler.com/newsbreak/fact-check/255727-putin-releases-tigers-lions-keep-people-at-home-russia-coronavirus

Claim: Breathing air from a hair dryer or a sauna can prevent or cure COVID-19
Explaination: This is false; an expert in coronaviruses said these methods would not be effective, while a cell biologist said there is no evidence the virus can be treated via heat.
Label: False
html:
Claim: Breathing air from a hair dryer or a sauna can prevent or cure COVID-19

Explanation:This is false; an expert in coronaviruses said these methods would not be effective, while a cell biologist said there is no evidence the virus can be treated via heat.

https://factcheck.afp.com/hot-air-saunas-hair-dryers-wont-prevent-or-treat-covid-19

Claim: Claim that photos show dogs being killed in China as part of efforts to combat COVID-19.
Explaination: Based on the evidence, AAP FactCheck found the post to be partly false. While there are media reports concerning pets being killed in China because of fears over the spread of COVID-19, they remain unverified and have been denied by authorities. The photos accompanying the Facebook post are unrelated to COVID-19. It is true that World Health Organization’s advice is there is no evidence that companion animals/pets can be infected with COVID-19 despite a single case in Hong Kong of a dog testing “weak positive”.
Label: Partially false
html:
Claim: Claim that photos show dogs being killed in China as part of efforts to combat COVID-19.

Explanation:Based on the evidence, AAP FactCheck found the post to be partly false. While there are media reports concerning pets being killed in China because of fears over the spread of COVID-19, they remain unverified and have been denied by authorities. The photos accompanying the Facebook post are unrelated to COVID-19. It is true that World Health Organization’s advice is there is no evidence that companion animals/pets can be infected with COVID-19 despite a single case in Hong Kong of a dog testing “weak positive”.

https://www.aap.com.au/these-photos-are-not-of-dogs-being-killed-because-of-coronavirus-fears/
